intro: Anthriscus hegetschweileri, commonly known as the Alpine chervil, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central and Southern Europe. It is a biennial or short-lived perennial plant that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters. The plant features finely divided, fern-like leaves and produces small, greenish-white flowers in umbels. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and herbal practices.
